A comparative study on FeOx-modified Pt/Nb2O5 catalyzing CO and propane oxidation has been conducted to differentiate the surface active sites demanded for these two important reactions. Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 displays improved activity for CO oxidation but decreased activity for propane oxidation compared to Pt/Nb2O5. Detailed characterizations reveal the alteration of the geometrical and electronic states of Pt species and surface acidity induced upon the addition of FeOx, thus clarifying the divergent catalytic responses in CO and propane oxidation. Pt-FeOx interface sites promotes oxygen activation that is a crucial step in CO oxidation, thereby accelerating the CO oxidation. However, the rate-determining step in propane oxidation is propane activation that requires the synergistic catalysis of acid sites and Pt0, the critical active sites for propane oxidation. The inferior activity of Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 in propane oxidation is explained by the coverage of acid sites and Pt species. Graphical Abstract Pt-FeOx interface sites promote the oxygen activation which is a crucial step for the CO oxidation, thereby accelerating the CO oxidation. Pt0 species and acid sites are the critical active sites for propane oxidation. ga1 Keywords Pt based catalyst Surface acid sites Pt0 species Pt-FeOx interface sites Propane oxidation CO oxidation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalytic complete oxidation reactions over heterogeneous catalysts have attracted increasing attentions because of its importance in the fields of both foundational research and practical applications. [1–4] In particular, the catalytic CO and hydrocarbons oxidation reactions are among the most investigated systems. For instance, developing efficient catalysts for the preferential oxidation of CO is vital for proton exchange membrane fuel cell in order to avoid the CO poisoning. [5,6] In addition, CO oxidation as one of the most fundamental model oxidation also plays important roles in the field of heterogeneous catalysis surface science. [7,8] Meanwhile, catalytic complete oxidation of hydrocarbons, such as alkanes, is widely present in the field of VOCs elimination and petrochemical industry. [9–11] Given that propane contains very stable chemical bonds, it is often used as one of most intractable model hydrocarbon to evaluate the activity of the designed catalysts. [12–14] Therefore, many catalysts have been developed for catalytic oxidation of CO and propane, including non-noble metal catalysts (CeO2, CuO, Co3O4, MnOx) [15–18] and noble metal catalysts (Pt, Pd, Ru) [19–21]. Pt-based noble metal catalysts have been successfully applied in many fields including these two oxidation reactions because of their high activity and thermal stability. [22,23] However, foundational research is still necessary to further increase the activities of Pt catalysts in CO and propane oxidation so as to save its cost due to the continuously increasing price of Pt metal. Although much progress has been made in the fields of both CO and propane oxidation, the nature of the active sites for CO and propane oxidation is still debatable up to now. Meng et al. [24] studied the active sites for CO and C3H8 oxidation by undergoing these two oxidation reactions over nanostructured CuO-CeO2 and Co3O4-CeO2 catalysts, and it was very helpful to clearly identify that the interface sites between CeO2 and CuO or Co3O4 were active for CO oxidation, whereas propane oxidation occurred on the neighboring surface lattice oxygen sites in CuO or Co3O4 crystallites. This finding suggests the different active sites demanded for CO and propane oxidation over non-noble catalysts, but it is still unclear for the Pt-based catalysts. In addition, most of the previous works only focused on one reaction of CO oxidation or propane oxidation, there is only rare research discussing these two oxidation reactions simultaneously, which is not beneficial for deeply and thoroughly identifying the active sites for CO and propane oxidation. In general, Pt0 species are the crucial active sites for CO oxidation, thus Pt catalysts are often pre-reduced before conducting CO oxidation, and oxygen vacancy is beneficial for the oxygen activation during the oxidation; [25,26] whereas the Pt0 specie or the ratio of Pt0/Ptn+ and acid sites significantly affect the activity of Pt-based catalysts in propane oxidation, [27,28] but the detailed reaction mechanisms over the active sites are not clear in the previous works. In addition, comparison of CO and propane oxidation over different Pt catalysts is also helpful for understanding the rate-determining step of propane because CO is one of the intermediates during the propane oxidation. More importantly, exhaust from cold-start vehicles simultaneously contains a large amount of CO and hydrocarbon components, which are in urgent need to be eliminated over a low-temperature oxidation catalyst. [29] Thus, more attentions should be paid to the activity of catalyst for both CO and hydrocarbons oxidation over the designed Pt-based catalyst. Herein, we employed Nb2O5 as the support which contains abundant acid sites for loading Pt catalyst, [30] and FeOx as the promoter to tune the Pt dispersion, surface acid sites and also the active sites for oxygen activation. Comparison of activities for CO and propane oxidation reactions over the Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts were conducted, and the kinetics of these two oxidation reactions over the representative catalysts (Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5) were also investigated. Combining with detailed characterizations, the active sites of the Pt-based catalysts in both CO and propane oxidation were disclosed, which is vital for further catalyst design. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Preparation of catalysts C10H5NbO20·xH2O was calcined at 700 °C for 3 h to obtain Nb2O5 support. [30] The Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts in this work were prepared by a facile impregnation or co-impregnation method. In typical, a certain amount of Fe(NO3)2∙9 H2O was dissolved in deionized water (2 mL), and Nb2O5 support (1 g) was added in the solution. Then, Pt(NO3)2 solution (5 mL, 2.0 mg mL−1) was dropped into above mixture under stirring, and the mixture was continuously stirred for 3 h at room temperature. Afterwards, the mixture was dried at 90 °C and kept in an oven at 100 °C for 5 h. The solids were calcined at 500 °C in static air for 4 h and the Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-xFe/Nb2O5 catalysts (x = 0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1, represents the weight percentage of Fe content in the catalyst) were obtained. 2.2 Characterization method Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface areas of these catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption in a BK200C system volumetric adsorption analyzer at 77 K. Prior to test, 100 mg of catalyst was dried at 100 °C for 12 h and degassed at 200 °C for 4 h. The actual Pt content in the catalyst was detected by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis on a Shimadzu XRF-1800 spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of catalyst was recorded on a Bruker D8 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation operated at 40 kV and 40 mA, the scan speed was 12° min−1 at 2θ of 10–90°. To measure the Pt dispersion of catalyst, the CO chemisorption test was performed on the BELCAT II analyzer at 30 °C after the pre-reduction of catalyst in a flow (5%H2 + 95%He) at 100 °C. Raman spectra were recorded by a confocal microprobe Raman system (Renishaw inVia Reflex) with an excitation laser of 325 nm (laser power =10 mW, dwell time = 60 s, number of scans = 100, resolution =1 cm−1). Field emission scanning transmission electron microscope (FE-STEM) images of the catalysts were obtained on a JEOL-2100 F microscope operated at 200 kV. Hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) test of catalyst was performed on a home-made tubular quartz reactor (i.d. = 6 mm) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to the H2-TPR test, the catalyst was pre-treated in a N2 flow of 20 mL−1 at 300 °C for 0.5 h. The catalyst (35 mg) sample was loaded on the reactor and then heated from 30 to 800 °C in a flow (5% H2 + 95% N2, 30 mL min−1) with the heating rate of 20 °C min−1, outlet gas from the reactor was dehydrated by 5 A zeolite and then introduced into TCD detector to record the signal. NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiment was also conducted on the home-made tubular quartz reactor equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). To clean the catalyst surface, the catalyst (200 mg, 60–80 mesh) was put in the reactor and pre-treated in a N2 flow (20 mL min−1) under 300 °C for 0.5 h, and cooled down to 50 °C. Then, high purity NH3 gas was flowed in the reactor (30 mL min−1) for 10 min, and N2 flow (20 mL min−1) was purged for 0.5 h to clean the gaseous or physically adsorbed NH3 on catalyst. Then, the catalysts were heated from 40° to 700°C in a high purity N2 flow (20 mL min−1) to desorb the chemical adsorption NH3, then outlet gas from the reactor was dehydrated by KOH and then introduced into TCD detector to record the NH3 signal, calculating NH3 desorption amount by fitting desorption peak area and using peak area of NH3 in a quantitative ring as reference. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) of CO chemisorption, in situ propane and CO oxidation on the Pt catalysts were measured on a Thermal-Fischer Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a MCT detector and a PIKE DRIFT accessory, the procedure was the same as that described previously.18,20X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained on an ESCALAB 250Xi instrument with Al Kα source. The binding energies (BEs) was calibrated by the carbonaceous C1s line (284.6 eV). 2.3 Catalytic activity testing The catalytic activities of catalysts for CO and propane oxidation were tested in a home-made tubular quartz reactor (i.d. = 6 mm) at atmospheric pressure. For CO or propane oxidation, a 50 mg portion of catalyst (60–80 mesh) diluted by 50 mg quartz was loaded in the reactor and then the reagent gas consisted of 0.6 vol% CO + 0.6 vol% O2 + 98.8 vol% N2 or 0.2 vol% C3H8 + 2 vol% O2 + 97.8 vol% N2 was flowed into the reactor at a rate of 66.6 mL min−1 with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 80000 mL g−1 h−1.. CO was analyzed online by gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a TDX-01 (3 m × 4 mm) capillary column and TCD detector, and propane was detected by a gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a DB-Wax (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm) capillary column and FID detector. Propane and CO oxidation reaction kinetics for two representative Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts were performed at differential reaction condition (with conversions below 15%), see the Supporting Information. The procedures were same to our previous work [18,20,21] The absence of mass and heat transfer limitations was verified following the Weisz-Prater and Mears’ criterion (see the Supporting Information). 3 Result and discussion 3.1 General characterizations Table 1 listed the surface area, actual Pt content and dispersion of the Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts. Low surface area of these catalysts can be ascribed to the nonporous structure of Nb2O5 oxide support, and it is also found that the addition of FeOx promoter slightly decrease the surface area of the obtained catalysts. Actual Pt contents in the catalysts are close to the nominal value due to the impregnation method used for these supported Pt catalysts. CO chemisorption results suggest the low Pt dispersion in these catalysts which is related to the low surface area of Nb2O5 support, and Pt dispersion of catalyst presents a volcano curve change with the increase of Fe content from 0 to 1 wt%. Among them, Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 shows the highest CO uptake of 12.3 µmol gcat −1, suggesting its highest Pt dispersion of 12.3%. It can be inferred that the FeOx promoter would affect the Pt dispersion. A low FeOx content favors the Pt dispersion on the Nb2O5 surface assigned to the segmentation effect of FeOx on Pt particles, whereas the exceeding FeOx specie lowers the Pt dispersion due to the coverage of over-amount FeOx on Pt particles. Segmentation effect of FeOx on Pt particles results in the smallest Pt particle observed in the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst. Similar results were also found in the other oxides promoted Pt catalysts in our previous works. 31,32 The XRD patterns, Raman spectra and STEM images of the Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1. All these catalysts show remarkable diffraction peaks at 2θ of 22.6, 28.4, 28.9, and 36.6° (Fig. 1a), which could be assigned to the orthorhombic Nb2O5 support (JCPDS No. 30–0873).25. The absence of diffraction peaks assigned to Pt and Fe species indicate their high dispersion or amorphous structures on the Nb2O5 support surface. There are two strong Raman vibrations appearing at 315 and 692 cm−1 for all the catalysts, which could be attributed to the orthorhombic t-Nb2O5 and low distorted octahedral NbO6 phases (Fig. 1b), respectively. [25] However, no Raman vibrations assigned to PtOx and FeOx species appear in the Raman spectra due to their too low contents. Nanoparticles of Pt species are observed on the Nb2O5 support surface according to the HAADF-STEM images of the Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts (Fig. 1c and d), and their size distributions are also evaluated by the particle statistics (insets). The Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst has a smaller mean size of Pt species than the bare Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst, thus consisting with the CO uptake result. Fig. 2 shows the HAADF-STEM-EDX element-mapping images of the representative Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst to further investigate the distribution of Pt and Fe elements. It can be seen that both the Fe and Pt species are uniformly dispersed on the Nb2O5 support surface, suggesting the existence of Pt-FeOx interface sites. Fig. 3 displays the H2-TPR and NH3-TPD profiles of the Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts. For the H2-TPR of the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst, the remarkable peak centered at 550 °C is ascribed to the reduction of Nb2O5 species, and its decreased reduction temperature in comparison with bare Nb2O5 support appearing at 750 °C in previous work can be ascribed to the hydrogen spillover from Pt to Nb2O5. [25] The reduction of FeOx species should appear at 400–500 °C, which overlapped with the reduction of Nb2O5 species. The increasing reduction peak appearing at 90 °C with the increase of FeOx content should be assigned to PtOx species. Whereas the absence of reduction peak corresponding to PtOx specie in the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst suggests that the PtOx specie could be reduced before the given temperature range. As previous works reported, PtOx specie could be reduced at a temperature lower than 30 °C [31] Such findings imply that the PtOx species on the Nb2O5 surface are easier to reduce compared to that on the FeOx surface. The Pt-1Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst has the highest reduction peak at 90 °C due to its highest FeOx content and most PtOx loaded on the FeOx surface. In the NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. 3b), the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst possesses the highest acidity, and the acidity decreases with the increase of FeOx content, implying the coverage of acid sites by the FeOx species. The new NH3 desorption peaks appearing at 100 °C after introduction of FeOx species hint the generation of weak acid sites, but the medium and strong acid sites obviously decrease due to the coverage of FeOx species. The above results also confirm the formation of Pt-FeOx interface sites, and the coverage of FeOx species on Pt species and acid sites. Fig. 4 displays the CO-DRIFTS spectra of the Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts. A weak absorbance peak at 1837 cm−1 observed on Pt/Nb2O5 is assigned to the bridged CO adsorption on Pt0 species. [31,32] Whereas this peak is absent in the spectra of Pt-Fe/Nb2O5, suggesting the FeOx covering or segmenting Pt species weakens the bridged CO on Pt species. Similar results are also observed on MoO3 modified Pt/ZrO2 catalysts. [31] Other two peaks at 2069 and 2092 cm−1 in the spectrum of Pt/Nb2O5 are assigned to linear CO adsorption on metallic Pt species surface with partially oxidized Pt species (Ptδ+) and completely reduced Pt species (Pt0), respectively. [33, 34] The peak at 2092 cm−1 disappears in the spectra of Pt-Fe/Nb2O5, suggesting that no partially oxidized Pt species (Ptδ+) existing on the catalyst surface. And linear CO adsorption on the Pt0 species slightly shifts to higher wavenumbers with the increase of the FeOx content, implying that the FeOx species closely interact with the Pt species and decrease the electron cloud density of the Pt species. 3.2 Activities evaluation for Pt catalysts Fig. 5 shows the light-off curves of CO and propane oxidation over the Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts. In Fig. 5a, the catalytic activities of Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts for CO oxidation firstly increase and then decrease with the increasing FeOx contents. Among them, the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst exhibits the highest activity for CO oxidation with a T 99 of only 100 °C, which is much lower in comparison with the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst of 220 °C. Mass specific reaction rate can directly describe the CO oxidation activity changes on these catalysts, it can be found that the highest mass specific reaction rate of 476.9 μmol gcat −1 s−1 for CO oxidation is observed on the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst at 60 °C (Table 1). Whereas, a very different tendency of propane oxidation activity is observed on the Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst. Mass specific reaction rate of these catalyst for propane oxidation decreases from 156.3 to 43.0 μmol gcat −1 s−1 with the Fe content increasing from 0 to 1 wt%, suggesting the inhibition of the FeOx species on propane oxidation over the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst. The Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst shows a T 99 of 350 °C for propane oxidation, which is obviously lower compared to the Pt-1Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst of 450 °C. These observations suggest the very different effects of the FeOx promoter for Pt/Nb2O5 in the CO and propane oxidation. Fig. 6 displays the stability performance of Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 for propane and CO oxidation. The Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst shows the robust catalytic activity for both propane and CO oxidation reactions. This observation not only suggests the stable structure of the active sites in Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 but also its potential application for CO and hydrocarbons elimination. 3.3 Discussion Fig. 7 shows the XPS spectra of selected catalysts to analyze the chemical states of surface Pt species. For the fresh Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst, there are six components in the deconvoluted Pt 4 f spectra. The components with binding energies at 71.6 and 74.8 eV are assigned to the Pt 4f 7/2 and Pt 4f 5/2 spectra of Pt0 species, respectively; while the components with binding energies at 72.7 and 76.0 eV correspond to the Pt 4f 7/2 and Pt 4f 5/2 spectra of Pt2+ specie; and the spectra of Pt 4f 7/2 and Pt 4f 5/2 attributed to Pt4+ species appear at 74.6 and 78.0 eV, respectively. [27,28,31] It can be seen that there is a few Pt0 species (6.3%) in the fresh Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst. Whereas the ratio of Pt0 species decreases with the increase of FeOx, Pt0 species is even absent in the Pt-1Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst with the highest FeOx content. This result can be ascribed to that the PtOx species on Nb2O5 surface is easier to be reduced as evidenced by H2-TPR (Fig. 3a) owing to medium and strong acid sites on Nb2O5 surface, whereas the FeOx species partially cover these acid sites. For the spent catalysts after CO oxidation, the chemical states of surface Pt species obviously change compared to the fresh ones (Fig. 7b), suggesting the reconstruction of surface Pt species during the CO oxidation. [34] The Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst possessing the highest medium and strong acid sites has the highest ratio of surface Pt0 species of 70.7%, which further confirms the promotional effect of these acid sites on the reduction of PtOx to Pt0. It is well known that Pt0 species are more active for CO oxidation compare to oxidized Pt species. Whereas the spent Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst for CO oxidation containing the highest Pt0 species shows the lowest activity for CO oxidation, even the spent Pt-1Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst only having 7.3% Pt0 species and lower Pt dispersion exhibits a higher activity compared to the bare Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst. These results suggest that the CO oxidation activity of catalyst is not only governed by the oxidation state of Pt, but the FeOx species might also play a crucial role. Certainly, Pt electronic states still affect the catalytic activity, the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst with higher Pt dispersion and more surface Pt0 species are responsible for its higher CO oxidation activity compared to Pt-1Fe/Nb2O5. For the spent catalysts after propane oxidation, the chemical states of surface Pt species also remarkably change (Fig. 7b). The spent Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst shows the highest ratio of Pt0 species of 63.6%, which also exhibits the highest catalytic activity for propane oxidation (Fig. 5a). In addition, surface Pt0 species on the spent Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst for CO oxidation (70.7%) is much higher than that for propane oxidation (63.6%), suggesting the PtOx species is easier to be reduced by CO in comparison with propane. Whereas, the Pt-1Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst containing the lowest ratio of Pt0 species (10.8%) possesses the lowest catalytic activity for propane. These results certainly confirm the reconstruction of surface Pt species during propane oxidation, and the critical roles of surface Pt0 species on activating and oxidizing propane. Our previous works also found the Pt0 species was of great importance for the activation of C-H bonds in propane. [27,28,31,32] Besides, the decrease of acid sites on the catalyst surface frustrated not only the reduction of PtOx but also the activation of propane, because acid sites were also recognized to be beneficial for activating C-C bonds of alkanes, [35,36] thereby resulting in the decrease of catalytic activity for propane oxidation over FeOx promoted Pt/Nb2O5 catalysts. In addition, the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst having a higher Pt dispersion and more exposed Pt sites shows the lower activity for propane oxidation as compared to the bare Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst, further suggesting that the coverage of acid sites by FeOx seriously decrease the activity for propane oxidation. Fig. 8 shows the in situ DRIFT spectra of CO oxidation over the Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts. The catalysts were sequentially exposed to CO, CO-O2 mixture, and N2 purge at 160 °C to record the spectra. For the CO purge, a peak at 2060 cm−1 observed for both catalysts corresponds to the linear CO adsorption on metallic Pt0 species, indicating that PtOx species could be easily reduced by CO, and the produced CO2 can be found at 2340 cm−1 31 The Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst shows much higher intensity of this CO adsorption peak than the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst, which could be attributed to that more acid sites in Pt/Nb2O5 promoted the generation of more metallic Pt0 species as discussed in XPS data, thereby resulting in the increased adsorption of CO. In addition, the peaks at 1600, 1512 and 1467 cm−1 can be ascribed to the asymmetric stretching vibrations of carbonate species (CO3 2-) accumulated on the catalyst surface, and the strong peak at 982 cm−1 can be assigned to the symmetric stretching vibration of CO3 2-. [37] These peaks only found in Pt/Nb2O5 during the exposure to CO and CO-O2 mixture suggests more carbonate species accumulated on its surface compared to Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5. This finding signifies that the carbonate species may be easily generated on the surface of Nb2O5 support and the FeOx specie inhibits the generation or promoted the decomposition of carbonate species for CO oxidation at 160 °C. It is still doubtable whether the accumulation of carbonate species affected the catalyst activity in CO oxidation, but the carbonate species can be easily swept by N2 purge, indicating the carbonate species can be decomposed and the catalyst surface change reversibly. In situ DRIFT spectra of propane oxidation over these two representative catalysts were also conducted as shown in Fig. 9. The spectra were recorded by sequentially exposing the catalysts to C3H8, C3H8-O2 mixture, and N2 purge at 220 °C. For the propane purge, a broad peak at 3000 cm−1 corresponds to the gaseous propane. Linear CO adsorption peak appearing at 2060 cm−1 is also observed for the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst but very weak for the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst, suggesting CO is one of the intermediates during propane oxidation, and PtOx can also be reduced to Pt0 species in propane gas. More Pt0 species are obtained in Pt/Nb2O5 due to its more acid sites. However, the peaks at 1540 and 1450 cm−1 only observed in Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 are assigned to carbonate species (CO3 2-) and methoxy (CH3O-), respectively; [38] and these peaks slightly increase with the purge time, suggesting the generation of carbonate species. For the purge of C3H8-O2 mixture, gaseous propane peaks disappear because fast propane oxidation reaction occurred on the catalyst surface in the presence of oxygen. Besides, an inverted peak appearing at 2060 cm−1 indicates the rapid consumption of intermediate CO adsorbed on catalyst surface with the presence of oxygen. Moreover, only the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst shows the remarkably increased peak attributed to carbonate species (CO3 2-) at 1600 and 1512 cm−1,20,30 This finding hints that the carbonate species prefer to generate on the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst rather than the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst during propane oxidation at 220 °C, which is very different from the carbonate species signal of in situ DRIFT spectra of CO oxidation at 160 °C. On one hand, the gradually disappearing carbonate species signals on Pt/Nb2O5 indicate the difficult generation of carbonate species on the Nb2O5 support surface during propane oxidation at a higher temperature (220 °C). On the other hand, Wang et al. found the introduction of H2O significantly enhanced the formation of formate species (1600 cm−1) for CO oxidation over Pt/Cr1.3Fe0.7O3 catalyst. [39] Therefore, it can be inferred that the formation of H2O during propane oxidation may promote the generation of carbonate species on the Pt-FeOx sites, thereby resulting in the increased carbonate species only on Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5. To further understand the different catalytic behaviors of CO and propane oxidation over the Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts, Fig. 10 shows the kinetic studies of propane and CO oxidation over the Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts. All the data were collected under kinetic control conditions (low propane and CO conversions, <15%), with the controlled C3H8/O2 or CO/O2 ratios in the range of 1/7.5–1/45, and mass and heat transfer limitations were excluded by the calculation of Weisz-Prater and Mears’ criterion [20,40] (see the Supporting Information). For the CO oxidation reaction, Fig. 10 a and b show the dependences of reaction rates on the partial pressures of CO and oxygen, respectively; and the detailed data are summarized in Table 2. The reaction rates increase with the increase of CO partial pressure for both catalysts. The derived power law rate expressions are r = 3.2 × 10−6 [CO]0.72 [O2]−0.66 for the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst, and r = 18.7 × 10−6 [CO]1 [O2]0 for the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst, respectively. A higher apparent rate constant k obtained on the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst represents its better catalytic activity for CO oxidation compared to Pt/Nb2O5, which is consistent with the apparent activity in the light-off curves (Fig. 5a). The reaction order of CO suggests the weak adsorption of CO on both catalyst surface, which was consistent with our previous works. [30] . Whereas, the reaction order of oxygen is very different for these two catalysts, the negative reaction order of oxygen observed on the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst suggests the competitive adsorption of oxygen with CO on the same active sites such as Pt species which is commonly recognized to be the crucial sites for CO and oxygen adsorption and activation; the zero reaction order of oxygen on the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst represents the saturated O2 adsorption on the catalyst surface, and the absence of competitive adsorption of oxygen with CO implies that the oxygen adsorption and activation occur on different active sites compared to that taking place on the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst. Ro et al. demonstrated that Pt-FexOy interfacial sites in Pt1Fex/SiO2 played very important roles in the oxygen adsorption and activation in the CO oxidation. [41] It was also reported that O-species supplied from FeOx at Pt-FeOx interfaces over a Pt-Fe/Al2O3 catalyst also accelerated the CO oxidation. [42] Thus, the FeOx species should also be the vital active sites for O2 adsorption and activation in this work, resulting in the enhanced catalytic activity of Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst in CO oxidation. For propane oxidation, the reaction rates increased with the increase of propane partial pressure for both catalysts (Figs. 10d and 10e). The derived power law rate expressions were r = 9.4 × 10−6 [C3H8]1.16 [O2]−0.37 for Pt/Nb2O5, and r = 1.4 × 10−6 [C3H8]1.08 [O2]0.28 for Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5. But a higher apparent rate constant k obtained on Pt/Nb2O5 suggests its higher activity for propane oxidation compared to Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5, which is very different with the CO oxidation. Near first reaction order of propane suggests the weak adsorption of propane on both catalyst surface. Whereas, the reaction order of oxygen is also very different for these two catalysts, the negative reaction order of oxygen observed on Pt/Nb2O5 suggests the competitive adsorption of oxygen with propane on the same active sites such as Pt species which is also the crucial sites for propane and oxygen adsorption and activation; the positive reaction order of oxygen obtained on Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 represents the absence of competitive adsorption of oxygen with propane. According to the kinetics of CO oxidation, the oxygen adsorption and activation could take place on the FeOx species in the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst which is very different from the oxygen activation on Pt species in Pt/Nb2O5, thereby eliminating the competitive adsorption of oxygen with both CO and propane. As apparent activation energy (Ea) shown (Figs. 10c and 10e), the addition of FeOx species in Pt/Nb2O5 significantly decreases the Ea from 38 to 20.2 kJ mol−1 for CO oxidation reaction, which can be attributed to the critical role of FeOx species on oxygen activation as discussed above. Thus, it can be further inferred that the activation of oxidation should be the rate-determining step in CO oxidation over Pt/Nb2O5. Whereas the Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst shows a much higher Ea (84.9 kJ mol−1) in propane oxidation compared to Pt/Nb2O5 (Ea = 76.5 kJ mol−1), indicating oxygen activation is not the rate-determining step for propane oxidation over Pt/Nb2O5. Based on the conclusions from XPS and kinetics, propane activation ability of catalyst depends on the synergistic catalysis of Pt species with acid sites and the promotion of acid sites on PtOx reduction, whereas the FeOx species cover the partial medium and strong acid sites, thereby resulting in the increased Ea for propane oxidation over Pt-Fe/Nb2O5. Namely, propane activation rather than oxygen activation is the rate-determining step in propane oxidation. According to the understanding above, the possible activation and oxidation of CO and propane over two representative Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt-0.2Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts have been proposed in Scheme 1. 4 Conclusion CO and propane oxidation over FeOx-modified Pt/Nb2O5 have been investigated to reveal the active sites demanded for these two very important model oxidation reactions in both foundational research and practical application fields. Compared with the Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst, the Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalyst shows much higher activity in CO oxidation but inferior activity in propane oxidation. The combined spectroscopic and kinetic studied reveal that Pt-FeOx interface sites could promote the oxygen activation, thereby accelerating the CO oxidation over Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 catalysts. However, FeOx species covering the partial medium and strong acid sites inhibit the activation of molecular propane and the reduction of PtOx to Pt0, thus resulting in the decreased activity in propane oxidation. These new insights are valuable for understanding the surface active sites of the Pt-based catalysts in CO and propane oxidation. coredata.dc:description: A comparative study on FeOx-modified Pt/Nb2O5 catalyzing CO and propane oxidation has been conducted to differentiate the surface active sites demanded for these two important reactions. Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 displays improved activity for CO oxidation but decreased activity for propane oxidation compared to Pt/Nb2O5. Detailed characterizations reveal the alteration of the geometrical and electronic states of Pt species and surface acidity induced upon the addition of FeOx, thus clarifying the divergent catalytic responses in CO and propane oxidation. Pt-FeOx interface sites promotes oxygen activation that is a crucial step in CO oxidation, thereby accelerating the CO oxidation. However, the rate-determining step in propane oxidation is propane activation that requires the synergistic catalysis of acid sites and Pt0, the critical active sites for propane oxidation. The inferior activity of Pt-Fe/Nb2O5 in propane oxidation is explained by the coverage of acid sites and Pt species.
coredata.dc:title: Identifying the surface active sites of FeOx-modified Pt/Nb2O5 catalysts in CO and propane oxidation
